awd_titl_txt: SFS: Cyber Security of Industrial Control Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Industrial Control Systems (ICS) are common components in critical infrastructure systems such as the smart power grid, smart buildings, oil and gas pipelines, chemical processing plants and water distribution systems.  Securing these systems requires a skilled and knowledgeable workforce with expertise in several engineering disciplines.  This project will develop new interdisciplinary courses, and modules that will be incorporated into existing courses, to enhance cybersecurity education.  The development of the curriculum will be guided by an advisory board consisting of industrial experts.  The graduates from these programs will possess the skills required to secure and maintain these critical systems.  

The goals of the project are (i) the training of future engineers/scientists to design, build and maintain secure industrial control systems, (ii) the development of new courses on security issues, (ii) the recruitment of students from underrepresented groups, (iii) the involvement of undergraduate/ graduate students for conducting design/ thesis projects in the secure industrial control systems ,(iv) the dissemination of the results through, web-based curriculum dissemination, and journal publications, and (v) outreach activities to community college and high school students.  Formative evaluations will continuously improve the curricula of the courses and a summative evaluation at the end of the grant period will evaluate the level to which the goals and objectives of the project have been met.  The data collected through the evaluation process will be use to improve program delivery as well as evaluate project success.

por.por_cntn:
The nation’s electric power grids, transportation systems, water and sewer systems, and oil/natural gas pipelines are some of the examples of critical infrastructure systems. In order to enhance the reliability, efficiency, resiliency and sustainability of these infrastructure systems, the advanced controls, communications and computations are integrated with industrial control systems. The integration of advanced communication and computations with the legacy industrial systems leads to various vulnerabilities for cyber- attacks. Approaches to secure critical infrastructure systems are based on the widely accepted philosophy of “defense-in-depth,” which dictates that security measures must not only to prevent unauthorized access through information technology (IT) portals, but must also integrate application-specific measures for intrusion detection and risk mitigation at every level, implemented with a complete understanding of the physical nature of the specific critical infrastructure systems. To ensure an effective and efficient long term program to protect industrial control systems, our nation needs a broad pool of workforce who are trained in an multidisciplinary format that addresses physical, cyber, and human elements with specialized skills in cybersecurity and artificial intelligence.

 

The principal objective of this capacity track project is to develop a curriculum program along with new interdisciplinary courses for enhancing the cyber security education/ training of electrical and mechanical engineering students in addressing the cyber security needs of industrial control systems. To ensure a constant supply of skilled and knowledgeable workforce to address the needs of protecting critical infrastructure systems we are proposing an educational program by expanding interdisciplinary courses and hand-on-laboratory experiments. One of the novelties is the interdisciplinary approach to the development of curriculum to address the cyber security of industrial control systems. The proposed curriculum consists of development of concentration areas in Electrical Engineering and Mechanical Engineering undergraduate curriculum by incorporating three newly developed courses incorporating defense-in-depth and design-in-security concepts in these elective courses. It is also proposed to include cyber security modules in some of the existing core courses. We also included industrial/ applied experience to students for enhancing the understanding of cyber security with industrial internships, interactions with industrial experts, and case studies involving penetration testing of industrial control systems. 

 

The major accomplishments of the project are: (i) development of new interdisciplinary courses in the area of Security of Industrial Control Systems for the benefit of undergraduate and graduate students, (ii) inclusion of cybersecurity topics into the existing courses, (iii) development of Industrial Control Systems (ICS) Testbeds, to provide intensive hands-on and penetration testing systems for research and training activities, (iv) recruitment  of students to participate in the “Research Experience for Undergraduates” projects, (v) organization of regular meetings of the interdisciplinary group of faculty and graduate students for the development research/curriculum activities in the area of Cybersecurity of Critical Infrastructure, and (vi) Organization of a “Workshop on Cybersecurity of Critical Infrastructure” at Texas Tech University in which participants from the industry and universities have identified strategies for training of students. Based on these strategies, we have developed the new courses. Availability of real time simulator and these courses enabled us integrate the cybersecurity concepts into curriculum of electrical and mechanical engineering programs.
